SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.vincestyling.asqliteplus
Class DBOverseer

java.lang.Object
  com.vincestyling.asqliteplus.DBOverseer

public class DBOverseer
extends java.lang.Object

This class exposes numerous handy methods to performing SQL statements, to be enable them, create a subclass and pass the SQLiteOpenHelper instance in.

All methods accepts the SQL as an Object, only its toString() matter. In other words, developer can constructing any Object such as String, StringBuilder, Statement to carrying the SQL statement, just make sure that the toString() method would return the final SQL statement you want to be executing.

getLastInsertRowId

public int getLastInsertRowId(java.lang.CharSequence table)
Fetches the newly inserted row ID of the specified table. Return 0 if the given table without an INTEGER primary key.

e.g. "select seq from sqlite_sequence where name = 'tbl_name'".

Parameters:
table - the name of the table.
Returns:
the row ID of the newly inserted row of the table.

executeInsert

public long executeInsert(java.lang.Object sql)
A convenience way to expose the SQLiteStatement.executeInsert() method.

Performs the SQL statement and return the ID of the row inserted due to this call. The SQL statement should be an INSERT for this to be a useful call.

Sometime, an INSERT could be creating more than one rows, e.g. "INSERT INTO tbl_name(...) SELECT ... FROM an_tbl_name", that the last created row ID would be returned.

Parameters:
sql - the INSERT SQL statement.
Returns:
the row ID of the newly inserted row if this insert is successful, -1 if an error occurred. Note as long as insert was successful, this execution will always return a positive value, even if the operating table did not creating as a table that holding an auto increment INTEGER primary key.
See Also:
SQLiteDatabase.insert(String, String, android.content.ContentValues)

executeSql

public int executeSql(java.lang.Object sql)
A convenience way to expose the SQLiteStatement.executeUpdateDelete() method.

Performs a single SQL statement that is NOT a SELECT or any other SQL statement that returns data. Would return the number of rows affected by execution of this SQL statement, thus usually used to perform a update kind's statement, including INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, CREATE-TABLE, DROP-TABLE etc.

Parameters:
sql - the SQL statement.
Returns:
the number of rows affected by this SQL statement execution.
See Also:
SQLiteDatabase.update(String, android.content.ContentValues, String, String[]), SQLiteDatabase.delete(String, String, String[]), SQLiteDatabase.execSQL(String, Object[]), SQLiteDatabase.execSQL(String)

getList

public <T> java.util.List<T> getList(java.lang.Object sql,
                                     java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
Performs the query and fetching the resultset to an ArrayList.

Advantage with the powerful Java Reflection, this approach accepted an entity class, mapping all the selected columns of row into that entity instance via invoke its setXXX methods at runtime. Which means we needn't hard-coding to perform those setter methods, just make the entity class obey the naming principle.

Type Parameters:
T - the generic entity which represent one row.
Parameters:
sql - the SELECT SQL statement.
clazz - the row's entity class.
Returns:
the resultset list.
See Also:
getEntity(android.database.Cursor, Class)

getPaginationList

public <T> PaginationList<T> getPaginationList(Statement sql,
                                               int pageNo,
                                               int pageItemCount,
                                               java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
Performs the query with two pagination arguments, computing and returning the desired PaginationList which contained four pagination informations.

First perform a query like "SELECT count(*) FROM (the original SQL statement lie here)" to determine how many rows of data are available. This allows the number of pages to be calculated.

Second, plus the pagination clauses to the original SQL statement, which would make it change like "[original SQL] LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20", finally perform that changed SQL to take the resultset.

Type Parameters:
T - the generic entity which represent one row.
Parameters:
sql - the SELECT SQL statement.
pageNo - the current page number.
pageItemCount - how many item a page have.
clazz - the row's entity class.
Returns:
the resultset list.

executeBatch

public <T> boolean executeBatch(java.util.List<T> list,
                                DBOperator<T> operator)
Looping the given List, put every item of that into the DBOperator to producing an individual SQL statement to performing.

Normally used to batch both SQL inserts, updates, and deletes, it does not make sense to batch select statements.

Note: All the batch update would be inside a transaction, which make us possible to avoiding data inconsistent by declare "INSERT||UPDATE OR ROLLBACK ..." form's statement whenever necessary.

Type Parameters:
T - the datasource generic type.
Parameters:
list - the batch datasource.
operator - the SQL producer by each item of the datasource.
Returns:
true if without any errors.

executeBatch

public <T> boolean executeBatch(T[] array,
                                DBOperator<T> operator)
See Also:
executeBatch(java.util.List, DBOperator)

See Also:
getEntity(android.database.Cursor, Class)

getEntity

protected <T> T getEntity(android.database.Cursor cursor,
                          java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
Fetching current row from the Cursor, instancing the specified Class and mapping each presented column's value associated with its name to the entity instance.

The names of columns in SQL statement played a big role here. For example: say the current row contained "nick_name, age, login_time" three columns, then the Class instance's setNickName(...), setAge(...), setLoginTime(...) would be invoke accordingly to mapping their values in.

Default naming principle accepted used underline(_) to separated each word in SQLite column naming; For Java, we followed the traditional naming which remove the underline character and Upper Case the first letter of each word. But that isn't fixed, in order to flexibility, the column name's translation pattern can be customize by overwrite the translateColumnName(String) method.

Notice: Because this approach was powered by Java Reflection, in order to prevent name mapping problems, it is important to tell ProGuard that which classes and members you wish not be obfuscated when you build your application in release mode.

Type Parameters:
T - the generic entity which represent one row.
Parameters:
cursor - the Cursor to map.
clazz - the row's entity class.
Returns:
the instantiated row entity.
See Also:
translateColumnName(String)

translateColumnName

protected java.lang.String translateColumnName(java.lang.String columnName)
Simply remove all the underline(_) characters to translating the name which used underline(_) to separated each word in SQLite column naming.

Parameters:
columnName - the original column name.
Returns:
the new name with all underline(_) removed.

debugSql

protected void debugSql(java.lang.Object sql)
Informing the SQL to be performing, by default, just print it to DEBUG level Logger when mIsDebug is true.

Implementations should overwrite this method to define other activities with the SQLs whenever necessary.

Parameters:
sql - the SQL to be perform.

public void setIsDebug(boolean isDebug)
Mark whether current in debugging mode or not.

Parameters:
isDebug - true indicate in debugging.
See Also:
debugSql(Object)
